results.title: What do I tell my children?
results.creator_credit: Aquarius Productions and Leslie Bellis Kussmann
results.brief_description: This video is internationally recognised as the most outstanding available for families and professionals who are dealing with children and grief issues, Children and parents share their stories and feelings about the loss of a loved one, while leading professionals in the field - including Earl Grollman, Elsiabeth Kubler-Ross, Sandra Fox and Anne Kilman - offer advice about coping and grief. It looks at practical advice for dealing with different kinds of bereavement: sibling, parent and grandparent.

results.title: What do I know about Benny?
results.brief_description: Benny is achieving low grades in school and his discipline is poor. His mother discuses the situation with the school principal. The principal attempts to explain that Benny was achieving up to his ability level. The mother rejects this and blames his performance on bad teaching.

results.title: What do girls want from boys?
results.brief_description: An open ended film from the “Searching years” series in which a group of young people discuss the problems of dating at high school level and the needs of girls in a close relationship. Why do girls often prefer to date older boys? What does a girl mean when a ask to be “treated like a woman?”

results.title: What do drugs do?
results.creator_credit: Multi-Media Productions and Mendelson Film Productions
results.brief_description: Examines the good and bad actions of drugs and chemicals on the body, the risks associated with drugs and the dangers of drug abuse. Emphasises that drugs should be respected both for their beneficial qualities and for their potential harm. Suitable for upper primary and secondary levels.

results.title: What did you do in the Great War Mummy?
results.brief_description: This film shows that there have traditionally been two labour markets in Britain based on the concepts of “mens” work and “women’s work”. Traces the history of women workers in the twentieth century with emphasis on the roles they played during the two world wars. These national emergencies shaped the change in attitudes regarding women and work, and during those conflicts, “a woman’s place” was no longer just in the home.

results.title: What did you do at school today
results.creator_credit: South Australian Film Corporation, John Morris and John Power
results.brief_description: Through an experience in outback camping in South Australia, a number of secondary school students learn the value of group co-operation. The decisions necessary to establish a comfortable and smooth-running campsite are made by the students themselves. Also, the shortcomings in their planning are shown - often humorously. Each student has an important part in a sequence of activities.

results.creator_credit_for_label: South Australian Film Corporation, John Morris and John Power

results.title: What depresses me ...
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Hidden depths”.
Psychotherapy, both in groups and singly, offers those suffering from depression a non-drug solution to their problems. In this program sufferers, psychologists and counsellors discuss the causes of depression (low self-esteem, childhood trauma from physical and sexual abuse, loneliness) and the value of psychotherapy and counselling. Professor David Smail outlines the three stages of therapy and stresses the importance of accurately assessing the limitations on resources for change available to each client and an awareness of the potential for client over-dependence on the comfort offered by the therapist.

results.title: What comes out of the blast furnace?
results.creator_credit: Merton Park, Frank A. Hoare and John Wiles
results.brief_description: In addition to iron, the furnace produces slag and gas. The film describes the uses to which all three can be put. Explains that the object of the blast furnace is the smelt iron, but in the process other things are also produced, such as slag which collects in the hearth of the furnace together with the hot metal, and gas, which passes out of the top of the furnace. Shows how these products are treated and the uses to which they are put. Makes the point that very little is allowed to go to waste in a modern iron works.

results.title: What can we do?
results.creator_credit: KQED-TV (Television station : San Francisco, Calif.) and Joanne M Mock
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Drugs: the children are choosing”.
The final films in the series looks at three different approaches to communication between adults and young people as they attempt to make decisions about life and drug. Includes scenes with pre-teens, teenagers, and college students. Urges all avenues of communication to be opened. From the series: Drugs: the children are choosing.

results.title: What can I do?
results.creator_credit: Callner Film Productions and Jerry A Callner
results.brief_description: The democratic system of government is a system meant for participation and involvement. Citizens can influence ongoing social change through personal political and social action. The use of the media, the impact of effective letters to the press and local members, and the power of the single vote are all examined.
